docs.snippet: Just about every piece on "I Have the Room Above Her," a honey of a record by the Paul Motian Trio, reaches a state of well-earned beauty....
docs.lead_paragraph: 'I Have the Room Above Her' Paul Motian Trio At some point in most songs by the Paul Motian-Bill Frisell-Joe Lovano trio, there's a subtle implosion, a folding-in on itself; the music gradually and elegantly resettles, like a sped-up film of a building shifting on its haunches over a century. The three of them -- on drums, guitar and tenor saxophone -- are working over a tune on three independent grids of rubato rhythm. When it's a real song-song, by Thelonious Monk or Bud Powell or Jerome Kern, as opposed to something more vague, Mr. Lovano tends to play the prow, establishing the melody with a broad, buzzy tone. Mr. Frisell, fitting three or five passing chords into a juncture where one might do, then adding a perfect and miniaturized Chet Atkins lick, lags behind Mr. Lovano a little. Mr. Motian remains out there darkly in the background, watchfully sketching around, never directly stating a pulse, tracing wide, loose melodic shapes with a small drum kit.
docs.abstract: Ben Ratliff reviews new CD by Paul Motian Trio; photo (M)

docs.snippet: A few trends are starting to appear in the opening days of Fashion Week: a linear silhouette, a surfeit of men's wear fabrics and a certain sexiness....
docs.lead_paragraph: Saturday evening on my way to a fashion show in Chelsea I passed a small clump of photographers waiting on the sidewalk for a V.I.P. to exit her white stretch limousine. Celebrities don't seem to enjoy going places alone, and apparently there is no thought of arriving in a taxi, so there was a brief wait while members of her retinue climbed out and patted down their jeans and sulkily stared at the photographers as if to make it clear who had the all-access pass to the free drinks. Meanwhile the traffic was beginning to back up, and someone near Ninth Avenue was laying on his horn. Finally the celebrity emerged -- her face didn't mean anything to me -- and the photographers were about to go to work when one of them said to a lady-in-waiting: ''Hey, pink jacket, would you move out of the way?''
docs.abstract: Cathy Horyn reviews fall shows of Jasmin Shokrian and other designers during New York Fashion Week; photos (M)

headline.main: Suits to Wear on Earth and in the Air

docs.snippet: It has been 25 years since Johnny Barnes portrayed Sugar Ray Robinson in "Raging Bull," and it is a role he has not stopped playing....
docs.lead_paragraph: Johnny Barnes cannot escape the role. It has been 25 years since Mr. Barnes, an actor, played Sugar Ray Robinson in ''Raging Bull.'' He is still called Baby Ray. Movie fans still stop him on the street. And for the last quarter-century he has enjoyed special status in Harlem poolrooms and boxing gyms.
docs.abstract: Johnny Barnes, actor who played Sugar Ray Robinson in film 'Raging Bull' has enjoyed special status in Harlem poolrooms and boxing gyms for last quarter-century; film is being shown at Ziegfeld Theater in Manhattan; many original cast members, including Robert De Niro, who played Jake LaMotta, and director Martin Scorsese attended 25th anniversary screening, but Barnes was not invited; photos (M)

headline.main: In This Corner, Baby Ray. His Opponent, Obscurity.; At Least Movie Fans Still Remember His Role in 'Raging Bull'

docs.snippet: The low-budget horror film ''Boogeyman'' (Sony Pictures), starring Barry Watson, right, of the television show ''Seventh Heaven,'' opened at No.1 over the slow Super Bowl weekend with an estimated $19.5 million in box office receipts. ''Boogeyman'...
docs.lead_paragraph: The low-budget horror film ''Boogeyman'' (Sony Pictures), starring Barry Watson, right, of the television show ''Seventh Heaven,'' opened at No.1 over the slow Super Bowl weekend with an estimated $19.5 million in box office receipts. ''Boogeyman'' is the second horror film from Sam Raimi's Ghost House Pictures. (''The Grudge,'' with Sarah Michelle Gellar, was the first.) Universal's romantic comedy ''The Wedding Date,'' starring Debra Messing and Dermot Mulroney, opened at No.2 with ticket sales of $11 million, playing well with female audiences (75 percent of the audience was women, half over the age of 30, the studio said). Rounding out the Top 5 were Sony's ''Are We There Yet?'' ($10.4 million in ticket sales), Fox's ''Hide and Seek'' ($8.9 million) and Warner Brothers' Oscar contender ''Million Dollar Baby'' ($8.7 million). CATHERINE BILLEY
docs.abstract: Arts, Briefly column; low-budget horror film Boogeyman leads weekend box office with estimated receipts of $19.5 million; photo (S)

byline.original: By CATHERINE BILLEY; Compiled by Ben Sisario

docs.snippet: Neil LaBute's ''This Is How It Goes,'' due to have its world premiere at the Public Theater next month, has found its final cast member: Marisa Tomei, right, the puckish Oscar winner (''My Cousin Vinny''). Ms. Tomei, who has also appeared in New Y...
docs.lead_paragraph: Neil LaBute's ''This Is How It Goes,'' due to have its world premiere at the Public Theater next month, has found its final cast member: Marisa Tomei, right, the puckish Oscar winner (''My Cousin Vinny''). Ms. Tomei, who has also appeared in New York productions of ''Salome'' and ''Wait Until Dark'' on Broadway, will play the romantic interest in a drama about an interracial love triangle in a small town, alongside Ben Stiller and Jeffrey Wright. George C. Wolfe, the outgoing producer at the Public, will direct. Previews begin on March 8. JESSE McKINLEY
docs.abstract: Arts, Briefly column; Marisa Tomei is signed to role in world premiere of Neil LaBute's This Is How It Goes, which is opening at Public Theater in March; photo (S)

byline.original: By JESSEMcKINLEY; Compiled by Ben Sisario

docs.snippet: BACK in 2003, in ''Kill Bill, Vol. 1,'' the Bride (Uma Thurman) began her rampage of revenge. In KILL BILL: VOL. 2 (2004), the best thing Quentin Tarantino has done since ''Pulp Fiction,'' she finishes it. As you'll recall, the Bride was attacked ...
docs.lead_paragraph: BACK in 2003, in ''Kill Bill, Vol. 1,'' the Bride (Uma Thurman) began her rampage of revenge. In KILL BILL: VOL. 2 (2004), the best thing Quentin Tarantino has done since ''Pulp Fiction,'' she finishes it. As you'll recall, the Bride was attacked by a gang on her wedding day and left for dead. But before she can have her final showdown with Bill (David Carradine), her onetime boss and lover, she has to deal with Budd (Michael Madsen), one-eyed Elle Driver (Daryl Hannah) and martial arts flashbacks with Pai Mei (Gordon Liu). She also has to discover that her little daughter is alive. The final scene, with Mr. Carradine and Ms. Thurman, is delicious, even when you see it coming -- Saturday at 9 p.m. and Saturday/Early Sunday at 3:45 a.m. on Starz. Tom Stoppard and Marc Norman's screenplay would be enough to make John Madden's SHAKESPEARE IN LOVE (1998) a joy. They've created an Elizabethan England where tavern waiters recite the day's specials and psychotherapists ask men, ''Have you lately been humbled in the act of love?'' But there's also Gwyneth Paltrow in the bloom of young love as the aristocratic Viola De Lesseps; Joseph Fiennes as William Shakespeare, her beloved; Judi Dench as a gloriously blunt Elizabeth I; and an ensemble cast that stands up to all of them. Look for Imelda Staunton, nominated for an Oscar herself this year for ''Vera Drake,'' as Viola's nurse. The film won seven Oscars, including best picture -- Saturday at 8 and 10:30 p.m. on Bravo.

docs.snippet: Having ripped the stuffing out of fashion so many years ago, why, at the age of 70, would Giorgio Armani want to join the rarefied ranks of the Paris haute couture?...
docs.lead_paragraph: The timing was impeccable. Giorgio Armani presented his Privé collection on Monday, Jan. 24, during the Paris haute couture shows. The Oscar nominations were announced on Tuesday the 25th. By the following Sunday, the entire collection would be in Los Angeles, red-carpet-ready for the army of stylists who were, according to Robert Triefus, the Armani Group's head of communications, falling all over themselves to get it.
docs.abstract: Giorgio Armani introduces his first haute couture collection; photo (M)

docs.snippet: Now that the president's State of the Union address has signaled the official start of the year, here are 10 rules for avoiding social, political and legal disaster in Washington....
docs.lead_paragraph: THE start of every presidential term brings to Washington eager new cabinet officers and members of Congress who take the wrong elevators, get lost in the hallways and pop off to reporters. But such faux pas -- Senator Ken Salazar, a freshman Democrat from Colorado, says he has not yet found the Senate dining room and is eating ham sandwiches in the public cafeteria -- are hardly the worst of it. As everyone knows, Washington is shadowed by the specters of grand scandals past: Richard M. Nixon and Watergate, Oliver North and Iran-Contra, Bill Clinton and Monica Lewinsky. More recently Bernard B. Kerik, President Bush's short-lived nominee for homeland security secretary, jettisoned himself for his troubles with a nanny and then turned out to have a Manhattan love nest, a serious no-no in Washington. Unlike New York, the nation's capital has always had a Puritan streak and remains a curious mix of raging ambition and Midwestern values.
docs.abstract: Newcomers would be well-advised to follow some rules of etiquette that could help them to navigate often-hazardous social avenues of politicallife in Washington (DC); photos (M)

headline.main: New to Capitol Hill? 10 Tips To Avoid Ruin
